verb.description: (of light or a source of light) shine unsteadily; vary rapidly in brightness.
examples: the interior lights flickered, and came on

verb.description: Make small, quick movements; flutter rapidly.
examples: the injured killer's eyes flickered open

noun.description: An unsteady movement of a flame or light that causes rapid variations in brightness.
examples: the flicker of a candle flame caught our eyes
then a flicker of movement caught his eye

phrases: I didn't have much more time to dwell on Claire's incompetence as a best friend, as they suddenly broke apart and the lights flickered out again.
The lights flickered out, sending the room into pitch darkness.
The flame from the arrow flickered out and everything went black again.
Sighing I was just about to give in to my sleep deprived brain and allow it some rest when the dome light flickered out.
But as soon as Hador had given his command, the lights flickered out and the room seemed to grow in the darkness that soon engulfed her.
origin: Early 19th century: imitative of its call.
